misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for a physics problem instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program is written for an average-acceleration physics exercise: it prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three double values. It never prompts for or reads the five integers required by the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and compute the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user for five integers (e.g., "Enter 5 integers:"), and use Scanner methods like nextInt() to read exactly five integer values from the keyboard.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Only three values are read instead of five
nextDouble() is used instead of nextInt() for integer inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different textbook example (average acceleration) instead of the required "sum of even numbers" problem, so their input handling matches the wrong problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the input section to ask for and read exactly five integers using nextInt(), not three doubles for v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt string and variable names (v0, v1, t) clearly correspond to a standard acceleration example, not to reading five integers.

evidence.note: The program prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three doubles, not five integers as required.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple required inputs
misconceptions.description: The code reads a fixed number of values (three doubles) sequentially with no for- or while-loop. For the intended problem, a loop is needed to process the five numbers systematically.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this task by calling nextDouble() a few times without using any loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process five numbers in a structured way, the program should use a loop (for or while) that iterates five times, reading one integer per iteration and updating the running sum.
symptoms: Exactly three calls to input.nextDouble() with no surrounding loop
No for or while structure appears in the code
Cannot easily scale to '5 integers' or any change in count
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented the wrong problem (average acceleration) which only needs three values, they never introduced the loop structure required for repeatedly processing inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop (e.g., for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)) that reads one integer each time and accumulates the sum within the loop body.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop of any kind; inputs are read with straight-line code despite the requirement to handle five numbers.

evidence.note: Three separate nextDouble() calls occur in sequence with no for- or while-loop.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even; it does not use the modulus operator (%) or any conditional related to evenness. As a result, it cannot distinguish even from odd numbers or restrict the sum to evens.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this (incorrect) acceleration problem, there is no need to test numbers with a condition like n % 2 == 0.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, each input value must be tested with a condition such as if (n % 2 == 0) before including it in the sum.
symptoms: No if-statement or boolean condition involving % or checking evenness
All input values (in the intended problem) would be treated identically with no filtering
misconceptions.root_cause: The student solved a different problem where even/odd classification is irrelevant, so they never implemented the required conditional logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer in the loop, add an if-statement like if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; } so that only even numbers contribute to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional logic or % operator at all, despite the requirement to sum only even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The core calculation uses an arithmetic formula for acceleration, with no conditional branch to test evenness.

misconceptions.name: Computes average acceleration instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: Instead of maintaining an accumulator for the sum of even integers, the program computes acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t and prints a physics-related message. There is no sum variable, no incremental addition, and the output label is unrelated to the required problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The goal is to compute and print 'The average acceleration' using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer sum initialized to 0, add each even integer to this sum, and finally print the result with a label like 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum.
symptoms: No accumulator variable for a sum
No additions that combine multiple inputs into a single result
Output text refers to 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
Core formula uses (v1 - v0) / t, unrelated to summing integers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have repurposed or copied an average-acceleration example, so the entire computation and output are aligned with that task, not with summing even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the acceleration formula with a sum accumulator: declare int sum = 0; add each even input to sum inside the loop; then print 'Sum of even numbers: ' + sum.
related_concepts: Designing output messages to match problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Both the variable names and printed message clearly correspond to an acceleration problem, and there is no accumulation of five numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The program computes an acceleration value and prints it, rather than summing even numbers and printing that sum.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code addresses wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t), which is entirely unrelated to the assignment objective of finding the sum of five even integers. Consequently, all core requirements, including input handling, looping, conditional logic, and accumulation, are missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code is the correct submission for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem (Q1), likely due to submitting the wrong file or completely misunderstanding the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The code must be designed to specifically address the problem statement: read five integers, filter for even numbers using the modulo operator (%), and calculate their sum.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration, not sum of numbers
Uses 'double' data type instead of 'int'
Reads 3 inputs instead of 5
Missing loop structure
Missing conditional logic (evenness check)
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment scope or major submission error where the code for an unrelated problem was submitted.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the supplied prompt (Q1. Sum of Even Numbers) and ensure the submitted file implements only that specific logic. If this was a submission error, please resubmit the correct file.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, variables, input prompts, and calculation are all demonstrably related to a different problem (acceleration calculation), showing a complete failure to meet the requirements of Q1.

evidence.note: The class name 'AccelerationCalculator' indicates a purpose unrelated to finding the sum of even numbers.
Reads three double variables instead of five integers, using prompts for v0, v1, and t.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Performs acceleration calculation instead of initializing a sum variable, using a loop, and applying conditional accumulation.

misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student’s program computes average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones. As a result, none of the required behaviors (reading 5 integers, looping, checking evenness, accumulating a sum) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for v0, v1, and t as doubles and then compute and print the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user once (e.g., 'Enter 5 integers:'), read exactly five integer values from the keyboard, use a loop to process those five inputs, check each number with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers into an integer variable, and finally print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by that sum.
symptoms: Prompt text is 'Enter v0, v1, and t:' instead of asking for 5 integers.
Program reads exactly three values (v0, v1, t) instead of five.
Inputs are stored as double rather than int.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional (n % 2 == 0) is used to filter even numbers.
Program prints 'The average acceleration is ...' rather than 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different textbook/example problem (average acceleration) instead of the specified task about summing even numbers, indicating a mismatch between the problem requirements and the solution they chose to code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Then design the program specifically for that task: change the prompt to request 5 integers, use int variables, add a loop that runs 5 times to read each integer, use an if (n % 2 == 0) check to decide whether to add the number to a running sum, and finally print the sum in the required format.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure and prompt of the program match a standard average-acceleration example and share no overlap with the required behavior (sum of even numbers from 5 integers). There is consistent evidence across variable names, prompt text, and formula.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation from three double inputs rather than reading five integers, looping, checking evenness, and summing even numbers as required.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation (Topic Mismatch)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration, completely ignoring the prompt which asked for the sum of even numbers among five input integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for a completely different programming problem (calculating acceleration) and submitted it for this assignment (Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must solve the specified problem: reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of the even ones.
symptoms: Code does not address the required functionality (summing even numbers)
Code takes 3 double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integer inputs
The class name is descriptive of the wrong task (AccelerationCalculator)
misconceptions.root_cause: Major failure to adhere to the assignment prompt. This is likely an oversight, submission error, or failure to start the task itself.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt carefully and write the required code using a loop, conditionals, and an accumulator to solve the problem 'Sum of Even Numbers'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calculates acceleration, which has zero overlap with the assigned task of summing even numbers. This is a definitive structural and functional mismatch.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a completely different program goal.
Reads three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of five required integers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Performs acceleration calculation instead of even number summation.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage for Inputs
misconceptions.description: The assignment requires reading integers, but the student's code uses `double` to read floating-point numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student used double for the inputs, perhaps believing it is safer or equivalent, which is incorrect for a problem explicitly requiring integer inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Integers should be read using `input.nextInt()` and stored in `int` variables.
symptoms: Use of `input.nextDouble()`
Inputs stored as `double` variables (`v0`, `v1`, `t`)
misconceptions.root_cause: The student selected the wrong type of variable and input method, possibly related to the overall issue where the wrong problem was solved (acceleration calculation often requires doubles).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: When the prompt specifies integers, always use the `int` data type in combination with `input.nextInt()`.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard (nextInt vs nextDouble)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The requirement is for integers (for even/odd checks), but the student used `double` inputs.

evidence.note: Inputs are read as doubles, not integers as required by the problem prompt (sum of even numbers).

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misunderstanding or Wrong Submission
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned sum-of-evens problem. This indicates either a file mix-up or a fundamental failure to read/understand the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the problem requires calculating acceleration from three velocity/time values, rather than summing even numbers from five integer inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading exactly 5 integers from input, filtering for even numbers (using n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum. No physics calculations are involved.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration formula instead of checking for even numbers
No loop to process multiple inputs
No modulo operator or conditional check for even/odd
Output message is about acceleration, not sum of evens
Code does not attempt any of the four rubric requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: Either the student submitted the wrong file/code by accident, or the student completely misread the problem statement and attempted to solve a different algorithmic problem entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: First, verify you have the correct problem statement. Then write a program that: (1) reads 5 integers in a loop, (2) checks each with (n % 2 == 0) for even, (3) accumulates a sum variable, and (4) prints 'Sum of even numbers: X' where X is the total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves an entirely different problem with zero overlap with the required solution. The code shows no attempt at any of the four core requirements (5-integer input, loop, even-check, accumulation). This is either a file mix-up or complete misunderstanding.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 doubles for a physics problem, not 5 integers for the sum-of-evens problem.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Code performs a physics calculation (acceleration formula) instead of summing even numbers. No loop, no even-check, no accumulation pattern.
Class name 'AccelerationCalculator' confirms this is code for a physics problem, not the sum-of-evens problem.
